text: [Music]
more than 2 000 years ago aristotle
outlined a formula on how to become a
master of persuasion in his work
rhetoric many great communicators have
used it throughout the ages to deliver
some of the most influential speeches
presentations and to share their ideas
with the world
ideas are the currency of the 21st
century the ability to persuade to
change hearts and minds is perhaps the
single greatest skill that will give you
a competitive edge in the knowledge
economy an age where ideas matter more
than ever
use aristotle's five rhetorical devices
in your next speech or presentation to
sell an idea attract investors build
brands inspire teams trigger movements
and become a master of persuasion
yourself
establishing your ethos or character is
vital if you want your audience to trust
you it's the part of your talk when your
audience gains insight into your
believability the story detailing your
time working with death row inmates
airlifting food to typhoon ravaged
communities or vaccines to underserved
populations if a speaker's actions don't
back their words they lose credibility
and ultimately their argument
so don't read out your degrees
accomplishments and awards
establish your character and build a
sense of trust between you and your
listeners after all humans are hardwired
to search for reasons to trust another
person
our ancestors had an instant to decide
if a stranger was friend or foe a simple
reminder that you are committed to the
welfare of others will build your
credibility before you lay out your
argument
next appeal to logos or reason
why should your audience care about your
idea how does it help them save money
earn a profit
what steps do they have to take next
these are logical appeals that will help
gain you support use data evidence and
facts to form a rational argument
pathos or emotion is the third and most
important device
according to aristotle persuasion cannot
occur in the absence of emotion people
are moved to action by how a speaker
makes them feel and the best way to
transfer emotion is through storytelling
21st century research backs this up ted
talk curator chris anderson finds that
when tales of failure awkwardness
misfortune or disaster are told
authentically they hasten deep
engagement and that the most personal
content is the most relatable and
neuroscientists report that stories
trigger a rush of oxytocin in the brain
the moral molecule that connects people
on a deeper emotional level
next comes metaphor which aristotle said
gives language its verbal beauty
when you use a metaphor or analogy to
compare a new idea with something that
your audience is already familiar with
you turn your idea from abstract to
concrete
warren buffett likes to say that he
looks for companies that are economic
castles surrounded by moats that make it
hard for competitors to enter the
industry use metaphor to turn words into
images it's a powerful tool that'll give
your audience a clear understanding of
your idea and will help them remember
and share it with others
and finally brevity is a crucial element
in making a persuasive speech an
argument aristotle said should be
expressed as compactly and in as few
words as possible he also observed that
the opening of a person's speech is the
most important since attention slackens
everywhere else rather than at the
beginning the lesson here is start with
your strongest point
the good news for communicators is that
aristotle also believed that persuasion
can be learned
and while the tools we use to
communicate ideas have changed in the
past 2000 years the human brain has not
the same formula that work then will
work now practice them to change
perspectives unleash human potential and
maximize happiness
[Music]
